comment.author: 7806261@N06
comment._content: Those dinners resulted in attendees being "rounded up" and sent to internment camps. Wonder what role the Samuel J Hood studios played? trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/92664741?searchTerm=Luck...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/miniop] oh dear, quite a damning report, however, so far in my research there seems to be the general consensus that no solid evidence to confirm that von Luckner was a spy for the Nazi regime.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 7806261@N06
comment._content: From my limited reading on line, which in no way substitutes for solid research, I'd agree. He played an interesting role negotiating the surrender of German troops at the end of the war. www.fof-ohlsdorf.de/kulturgeschichte/2006/92s34_luckner.htm If anything he seemed to be a most adaptable character.
